questions.question: In the video shown in the cogging module, the material is:

explanations.a: Steel is commonly used in cogging demonstrations due to its high-temperature workability.
explanations.b: Aluminium is forgeable but was not used in the given simulation.
explanations.c: Copper is used in forming, but not in this module’s demonstration.

questions.question: The press used in the simulation of cogging operation is:

explanations.a: Cogging requires controlled, slow, and high-force compression—hydraulic presses are ideal for this.
explanations.b: Screw presses deliver impact, not slow continuous pressure.
explanations.c: Mechanical presses are used for high-speed operations, unsuitable for cogging.
explanations.d: Incorrect because hydraulic press was used.

questions.question: The temperature of the billet used in the simulation of cogging process is:

explanations.a: Cold cogging is impractical as the forces required would be extremely high.
explanations.b: 100°C is far below forging temperature for steel.
explanations.c: Steel is typically cogged at 1100–1250°C, making this the correct hot-working temperature.
explanations.d: Incorrect as 1100°C matches standard forging temperature.

questions.question: The number of passes used to convert round billet into square billet in cogging process simulation are:

explanations.a: Two passes are insufficient to obtain a square section from a round billet.
explanations.b: Three passes still do not generate a fully square shape.
explanations.c: Four passes (with 90° rotations) are standard to convert round to square.
explanations.d: Eight passes would be excessive for a simple square section.

questions.question: Which of the following material cannot be cogged:

explanations.a: Steel is widely cogged at high temperature.
explanations.b: Aluminium can be cogged easily due to good ductility.
explanations.c: Lead is soft and can undergo plastic deformation, so it can also be cogged.
explanations.d: All listed materials are forgeable and can be cogged, so none of them is excluded.
